background_context.situation: Engaged with a community organization to meet new people.
background_context.environment: Uses the organization's website primarily for event information.
background_context.constraints: Time constraints due to a busy schedule.

goals_motivations.drives: To meet new people and participate in community events.
goals_motivations.achievements: Desires clear and accessible information about events.

behaviors_patterns.current_work: Primarily interacts with the events calendar on the website.
behaviors_patterns.habits: Checks the website for events, prefers calendar view for quick access.

pain_points_frustrations.obstacles: Frustration with events being waitlisted and lack of easy cancellation options.
pain_points_frustrations.issues: Overwhelmed by excessive information and tabs on the website.

needs_desires.improvement: Wants a streamlined website with easy access to event availability and cancellation options.
needs_desires.looking_for: A more efficient way to view event capacity and manage registrations.

attitudes_beliefs.mental_models: Values simplicity and clarity in navigation.
attitudes_beliefs.preferences: Prefers to see essential information without unnecessary content.

technical_comfort.tools: Uses the organization's website, familiar with basic web navigation.
technical_comfort.abilities: Comfortable with technology but prefers not to engage with overly complex interfaces.
technical_comfort.learning_preferences: Learns best through direct, hands-on experience rather than extensive reading.

quotes: I only really care about like when I go to the site, I want to... see what the goal of the organization is.
I typically use the events calendar view just because it has it laid out in a way where I can see it the month at a glance.
If I see wait list for every single thing I'm interested in, then I kind of stop looking at the website too.
